description.narrative: The primary objective of the Resilience Programme is to strengthen Cambodia’s resilience in the context.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1. Number of public policy and surveys related to modelling of the socio-economic impacts of Covid informs government's stimulus package that protects both the economy and the most affected and vulnerable groups 1.2. Number of quick survey tools to assess economic conditions and impacts 2.1. Number of Poor Households affected by Covid 19 access to On Demand Identification poor household 2.2. Number of informal sector workers access to social insurance(the missing middle) 3.1 SPS protocols available to maintain flow of all physical goods with Viet Nam, Lao and Thailand 3.2 Acceleration of E-commerce uptake during and post Covid19 crisis and formalization of MSMEs in Cambodia 3.3 Australia-Cambodia Partnership for Consumer Protection

comment.narrative: - No survey conducted on MSME/ socio economic impacts - On-demand registration of Covid affected poor household not operationalized - No strategy for inclusion of missing middle/ informal sector workers (estimated at 4 million workers); no means of making COVID-19 support; No formal registry of informal sector workers (estimated at 4M workers) - No sanitary protocols for pandemic case - Onboarding of small producers and service providers in essential sectors not effective and not prioritized - Ad hoc, unstructured, administrative communication only

- Stimulus/ Covid response of least 3% of GDP, with clear focus on the most affected groups and vulnerable populations (% of stimulus). - Survey conducted for at least 2 sectors (MSME and informal sector) - On-demand registration of Covid affected poor household not operationalized in 25 municipality/ provinces - Basis of a strategy to tackle the SP challenges faced by the missing middle is in place; and Options are set-out to enroll informal sector workers in the social insurance system, enabling rapid disbursement of COVID-19 reliefs. - SPS Protocols developed and tested at Viet Nam, Laos and Thailand borders for flow of goods (3 border points) - 1). Small producers, sellers and service providers in essential sectors maintain continuity of business through online channels: 1000 businesses enrolled in marketplaces in 3 provinces (40 are women-led businesses); 2). 2,000 farmers connected to online agriculture platform providing access to easy to access agriculture supplies, technical and credit supports; 3). New jobs created: 500 (300 in PP, 100 in SRP, 100 in BTB, 50% are women)

- Completed COVID-19 Economic and Social Impact Assessment using CGE modelling and GTAP Stimulation, with a close partnership with MEF, to evaluate the impacts on economic growth, poverty and employment. - Launched and published Policy Brief in October 2020, with the support from DPM, Minister of Economy and Finance. - Economic modelling technical assistance has shaped the Government’s stimulus packages to support the most vulnerable people through social protection programmes. As a result, the RGC has moved quickly to put in place a set of policy measures and a stimulus package of around 4.3 percent of GDP (i.e., approximately US$1,164 million), including cash transfers to poor households (US$300 million), cash for work (US$100 million), wage subsidies to workers in garment and tourism sectors (US$64 million), and support to SMEs (US$600 million). - Completed the virtually delivery of the first-round training on macroeconomic modelling by one international and one national macroeconomic modellers to MEF’s team working on the national Covid-19 economic response. Certificate handout was held in October 2020. - The longitudinal, national surveys of informal workers and MSMEs consist of three waves, and Kantar Ltd was contracted to conduct this research project. The first wave was conducted in July 220 (n=1,392 for informal workers; n=514 for MSME surveys). The second one was completed in October 2020 while the third one will be done in January 2021. The survey data has been integrated into the interactive dashboard that will be soon made publicly accessible. - 1,700 tablets and software to the Ministry of Planning along with training for rapid and accurate registration of citizens into Cambodia’s social protection identification system. - 674,146 poor households affected by COVID-19 gained access to the Government’s cash transfer programme - Three regional trainings on OD-ID Poor and cash transfer programme, provided to the provincial departments of planning, PoSVY and commune/Sangkat. - Angkor Research Consulting Ltd has been recruited to conduct the socio-economic impact assessment of Covid-19 cash transfer program. To capture the effects of cash transfer over an extended period, a longitudinal tracer study (n=1,000) has been employed in this study on randomly selected Poor 1 / Poor 2 card holders and non-IDpoor holders at regular intervals. The fieldwork will be conducted in the fourth week of December. Follow-up phone interview will be administered in two waves—January 2020 and February 2021. - The rapid assessment has been conducted at 3 mainland borders checkpoints and 1 international airport custom and excise branch on the challenges and constraints hindering the flow of cross-border trading activities, as well as the risks imposing to associated persons working at the borders. - The internal guideline and sanitary and health protocol has already been drafted, while the personal protective equipment (PPE) and sanitary equipment has been procured in parallel and supplied to GDCE. Thereafter, the training to the GDCE officials and relevant associated persons at the land border and international airport will be conducted at the onset or virtually as deems necessary to ensure the application of safety measures which would contribute to the acceleration of the trade facilitation process. - Two assessments on the extra capacity needs of the E-commerce marketplace and the vendor readiness for e-commerce uptake are completed. The assessments aim to understand both the existing e-marketplace capacity to onboard more vendors and the readiness of vendors/SMEs for e-commerce uptake. 25 online marketplaces were interviewed, and one consultative workshop took place with approx. 30 representatives from business associations, local vendors/sellers, and e-marketplace to validate the study results. - Through boosting farmers’ income through access to agri-tech platform initiative, 1,200 smallholder farmers growing rice and vegetables, in five provinces, were identified and are registered in the digital application- called Agribee. These farmers are trained to use the application for various farming purposes such as purchase inputs, access to extension services, and sell their products. - In term of job creation, UNDP is working closely with the National Employment Agencies to organize a series of Career Forums both online and offline, taking into account the COVID-19 prevention measures, in early next year in three geographical areas including Phnom Penh, Siem Reap and Battambang to link idle capacity to the career opportunities which are newly created from this e-commerce uptake of MSME and the upscaling of the business operation of e-marketplaces.

- Stimulus/ Covid response of least 3% of GDP, with clear focus on the most affected groups and vulnerable populations (% of stimulus). - On-demand registration of Covid affected poor household not operationalized in 25 municipality/ provinces - Basis of a strategy to tackle the SP challenges faced by the missing middle is in place; and Options are set-out to enroll informal sector workers in the social insurance system, enabling rapid disbursement of COVID-19 reliefs. - Survey conducted for at least 2 sectors (MSME and informal sector) - 1). Small producers, sellers and service providers in essential sectors maintain continuity of business through online channels: 1000 businesses enrolled in marketplaces in 3 provinces (40 are women-led businesses); 2). 2,000 farmers connected to online agriculture platform providing access to easy to access agriculture supplies, technical and credit supports; 3). New jobs created: 500 (300 in PP, 100 in SRP, 100 in BTB, 50% are women) - Quarterly Microsoft Teams conferences, with a targeted agenda with standing and rolling agenda items.
